title: How to use the most simple way to do authentication?
TLDR: when user issues a sign in request, store the key of user and expired info into something called
session
c
in the server (with a key-value store), and then we derive a
signature
c
of
session
c
‚Äôs key, which will return to client and stored in
httpOnly Cookies
c
For a newbie, you got confused, but somehow you know how to use a library
Ok, we use a library, but do you know what does the library do and why does it do that?
From client‚Äôs perspective, we all know a user need to register with a username and password to create a
account
c
, but somehow we need to keep user signed in, that means the server need to persist something in the client side
Luckily, we‚Äôve got
cookies
c
, and this is exactly what cookies does
From server‚Äôs perspective, how the hell does it know you are Alice or Bob?
This is when we need a
session
c
, server usually needs to handle different client‚Äôs request, the mapping of client and user is what we called a
session
c
, that‚Äôs why server usually needs a key value store
Imagine you have different conversation with your friends on the phone, each convo window is a
session
c
for you, and you know who you talking to by looking at the conversation window
Identify a window is easy for you because you are a human being, but for server, it needs a id to know what session it‚Äôs handling so that it could serve the right user
So the server just return to client and ‚Äútag‚Äù the client with a session id, with
cookie
c

We don‚Äôt need to put all the user information, because other information such as user‚Äôs role might change, you just need to query user‚Äôs role with other relational database, so we need to just put the user id

Also a expiration time needs to be put, because you usually don‚Äôt want a user to be logged in forever if they are not active, plus it‚Äôll get easy for others to exploit if a token like this is not rotated constantly
Same with other kinds of auth like API key and passwords, if you keep that stale forever, it might leave a longer window for hackers to exploit your credentials
You might ask if session gets expired constantly, don‚Äôt users need to constantly log in?
Actually, the client side could choose to refresh the session if needed, this will stop annoying the user while keeping them safe, but that will be another topic to discuss
One thing very important about session cookie is,
we don‚Äôt store the actual session data on the client side
b
, why?
That‚Äôs because the client already knows who the user is, and it only needs to show the session id every time to the server as a pass token
Then, server will quickly check if such a key exists in its store and check if the session has been expired
That‚Äôs why server needs a random id instead of a predictable id, in express, they use
uid-safe
c
module
This is what a cookie in express look like:
After decoding
s%3A
c
, we get
s:
c
, which means this is a signature, a formatting thing
From this, you can see
h30wc0pvSHJCYLVz0tui0Cv6NCCexGV8
b
c
b
is the id, and the part after the dot is the signature of the id
Why do we need a signature?
This is to avoid the tampering of the original cookie, so not only a key is enough, we still need to make sure the key is issued by the server, this is similar to other auth methods like JWT
Because a signature is involved, we need a secret on server in order to sign things, we usually set environmental value for that
When
httpOnly
c
is set to
true
c
in a cookie, it actually prevent the front end from accessing it, this could avoid the cross site scripting attack
You actually don‚Äôt need to worry all of that by yourself, because
express-session
c
is going to do that for u!
We only need to install the package using
npm i
c
, then we can include it in our global middleware
You can refer to this answer:
When to use saveUninitialized and resave in express-session
description: Let's assume that sessions are enabled globally (for all requests). When a client makes an HTTP request, and that request doesn't contain a session cookie, a new session will be created by express-session.

title: Simply put,
saveUninitialized
c
set to false could avoid a lot of unused empty object being stored, because if it set to true, all the request will create a session store if it‚Äôs still uninitialized
And
resave
c
set to true will be able to rewrite the
req.session.cookie
c
, this will allow the scenerio of two browser logged in together, one request log out will also log out the other session
Also we have
rolling
c
, this will allow the session middleware reset a new cookie when it gets expired
Then we can access the session data with
req.session
c
The default session would be using memory, to prevent session sticky when doing replication of backend, we can choose to use Redis to as a single store of truth, but we will not cover this
In the route of login, we can modify the state of
req.session
c
to allow the session store to write things, note that it‚Äôs better not to put the entire user in it, as the state of the user could be modified

We can write another middleware in front of the route that needs to be authenticated (is the user logged in), we can even write another middleware to do authorization (does this user have access to the data?)
Why two layers? this is to avoid the coupling
When log out endpoint is triggered, you only need to call
req.session.destroy()
c
to destroy it

So, that‚Äôs a wrap, maybe I will also cover JWT in the future, but I don‚Äôt really find JWT more appealing to me as it shifts more responsibility onto the front end which is quite annoying so it will never be simple to anyone

This is my first attempt try to write a simple explanation article about dev and I try really hard to divide the information in chunks and sections (and I try to avoid writing multiple sentences in a praragraph)

name: fluidfeed
description: turns what i‚Äôve learnt about dev in words
